Retrieved August 10, 2011.</ref> In 2008, the chaplain of the Veterans Affairs hospital in [[Fayetteville, North Carolina]] resigned when Christian symbols were removed from the hospital chapel—after complaints of religious insensitivity regarding chapel symbols were lodged following a non-denominational ceremony in that chapel to remember victims of the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref name="vachapel"/>
<center> <gallery> Image: Camp Bondsteel Chapel.jpg|Chapel at [[Camp Bondsteel]] in [[Kosovo]], during Presidential visit. Makeshift crosses later erected on chapel grounds were removed. Image:NNMC Bethesda Chapel 2.jpg|Chapel at [[National Naval Medical Center]] (Bethesda, Maryland) had crescent added to symbols of cross and Star of David, June 1998 Image:Chapel on the Thames.jpg|Chapel on the Thames, Naval Submarine Base New London (Groton, Connecticut), where rooftop cross was removed, then restored Image:Frazier Hall NAVSTANORFOLK.jpeg|Chapel Complex, [[Naval Station Norfolk]], with crosses on Protestant and Catholic Chapels in building that also includes Jewish and Muslim chapels </gallery> </center>
====Erecting and removing religious symbols apart from chapels==== A slightly different issue involving a cross on a military base—but erected separately from a chapel as a memorial to marines killed in Afghanistan—involves a 13-foot cross erected on top of a hill at Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton, in California.<ref name="pendletoncross">Schapiro, Jeff, The Christian Post, [http://www.christianpost.com/news/aclj-veterans-cross-should-stay-62640 "ACLJ: Veterans Cross Should Stay," November 21, 2011]. Retrieved December 11, 2011.</ref> The [[American Center for Law & Justice]] is arguing on the part of those who erected the cross that it should be allowed to stay because "crosses are used as a widespread and universal symbol of remembrance," not just as religious symbols, while other groups, such as the Military Association of Atheists and Freethinkers, are arguing that the cross should not be allowed to remain.<ref name="pendletoncross"/> A similar cross was erected in 2003, but was destroyed in a fire, so the new cross has been created with "fire-retardant" material.<ref name="pendletoncross"/> A spokesman for Camp Pendleton was quoted as saying that the Camp Pendleton "legal staff is carefully researching and reviewing the topic in order to make a balanced and unbiased command recommendation that is ultimately supported by the law."<ref name="pendletoncross"/>
====Vandalism using religious symbols==== [[File:USAFA stone circle.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Dedication of the "Cadet Chapel Falcon Circle" at the [[United States Air Force Academy|U.S. Air Force Academy]] for "Earth centered" worship]] In 2010, vandals used a religious symbol in a negative way, adding a wooden cross to a non-Christian military worship area as an apparent attempt to make an anti-religious statement against the "[[Earth religion|Earth-centered"]] worship area ("stone circle") set aside at the [[United States Air Force Academy]] (USAFA) for the use of adherents of faith groups that identify themselves as "[[Paganism (contemporary religions)|Pagans]]," such as Wiccans or Druids.<ref name="stonecircle">[http://www.gazette.com/articles/crime-93686-hate-examples.html www.gazette.com]. Retrieved June 10, 2011.</ref> According to the local [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] gazette, "Whoever left the cross exploited the most sacred object of Christianity for an act of confrontation."<ref name="stonecircle"/>
Lieutenant General [[Michael C. Gould]], USAFA Superintendent, said that it was important that the academy support the religious needs of all cadets, and that [https://web.archive.org/web/20120303205729/http://www.adr.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-070216-034.pdf USAF Instruction 36-2706] gives air force leaders guidance in terms of defining "religion" as "a personal set or institutional system of attitudes, moral or ethical beliefs and practices held with the strength of traditional religious views, characterized by ardor and faith and generally evidenced through specific religious observances."<ref name="gould">[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/02/05/cross-placed-air-force-pagan-circle-prompts-probe www.foxnews.com]. Retrieved June 10, 2011.</ref>
Gould said that the incident was being taken very seriously, because respect for the religious beliefs of others is an especially important lesson for USAFA cadets, who "learn that to succeed as an Air Force officer we must be able to support and respect the people who we lead, serve with and fight alongside even if they do not share our personal beliefs.... Cadets learn that every servicemember is charged with defending freedom for all Americans and that includes the freedom to practice a religion of their choice or to not practice any religion at all."<ref name="gould"/>
Academy officials took actions to send a clear message that the "Cadet Chapel Falcon Circle," the area set aside for Earth-centered worship, "is to be treated with respect and dignity, just as any other religious structure or location."<ref>[http://www.gazette.com/articles/academy-93565-longcrier-worship.html www.gazette.com]. Retrieved June 10, 2011.</ref>
===Lack of symbols as symbol=== It has been pointed out that in some ways the lack of permanent symbols itself becomes a symbol: "a visible symbol of how people of different beliefs can not only tolerate one another, they can live in the same house." <ref name="MacDill">Shelton, Janet, [http://www.catholicweb.com/media_index.cfm?fuseaction=view_article&partnerid=30&article_id=440 "The Air Force base’s chapel meets many faiths’ needs to serve Catholics and Protestants"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114190407/http://www.catholicweb.com/media_index.cfm?fuseaction=view_article&partnerid=30&article_id=440# |date=2011-01-14 }}, www.catholicweb.com. Retrieved May 21, 2011.</ref> Father Dennis Hanley, Catholic chaplain for [[MacDill Air Force Base]] said in an article for "Catholicweb.com" that reported on the shared usage of MacDill Air Force Base chapel spaces, including the way that temporary religious symbols were changed depending on the faith group holding the worship service, that "Military chapels are a model for interfaith ecumenical cooperation."<ref name="MacDill"/>
==Symbols in National Cemeteries== [[File:Two VA religious symbols.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Two examples of more than forty religious and belief system symbols authorized by the Veterans Administration for use on headstones and markers in National Cemeteries. Left to right: [[Russian Orthodox]] cross and Wiccan pentacle ([[pentagram|"circumscribed" pentagram: pentagram within a circle]])]] {{Main|United States Department of Veterans Affairs emblems for headstones and markers}} The history of government issued headstones predates the Veterans Administration and the National Cemetery Administration, with roots that can be traced back to America's frontier days, when garrison commanders took on the responsibility of burying their soldiers.<ref name="headstones">[http://www.cem.va.gov/hist/hmhist.asp www.cem.va.gov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022005906/http://www.cem.va.gov/hist/hmhist.asp |date=2011-10-22 }}. Retrieved June 10, 2011.</ref> However, it was not until the creation of the national army that was established at the beginning of the Civil War that army regulations (General Orders Number 75, September 11, 1861) assigned the national commanders of the military with the responsibility for burials and grave markings—and the Quartermaster General of the Army was tasked with providing the actual "headboards."<ref name="headstones"/> Much later, following World War I, a board of officers approved the white marble headstone, slightly rounded at the top—and for the first time, two specific religious markings (the Latin Cross for Christians, and the Star of David for Jews) were authorized for use.<ref name="headstones"/> Changes in construction and designed continued to be made, and in February 1951, he Secretary of the Army approved the addition of a Buddhist emblem in addition to the Cross and the Star.<ref name="headstones"/>
Today, the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs]] (VA) establishes policies for religious symbols on headstones and markers in [[United States National Cemeteries]], although the [[United States Department of the Army|US Department of the Army]] continues to oversee two of them, including [[Arlington National Cemetery]].<ref name="VA"/> In contrast with the small number of religious symbols that have been approved by DOD over the years for chaplain insignia, the VA has approved over forty five separate religious symbols for use on cemetery headstones and markers (those used in national cemeteries and those issued to families of eligible veterans for use in private cemeteries) and has a process in place to consider and approve additional religious symbols based on requests by the next of kin of the deceased.<ref name="VA"/>
Although current procedures allow for speedy approvals of new religious symbols, the pentacle (the pentagram within a circle), the symbol now used for Wiccan headstones and markers, was approved only after ten years of efforts that concluded with a lawsuit against the VA, resulting in a settlement that accorded that symbol the same status as any other religious or belief system allowed.<ref name="cemetery">Miller, Geralda [http://www.rgj.com/article/20070424/NEWS10/704240336/Wiccan-symbol-now-official-national-memorials "Wiccan symbols now official for national memorials], RGC.com. Retrieved May 23, 2011.</ref>
[[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]] represented the plaintiffs, saying that "we uncovered evidence that the reason the pentagram hadn't been approved was straightforward religious bias.... The Justice Department knew that if they didn't do the right thing, then a federal judge would tell them to and, in the process, would state very publicly all the things they've done wrong over the past decade."<ref name="cemetery"/>
The first "interfaith" headstone—including a [[Wicca]]n [[Pentacle]] for Jan Deanna O'Rourke and a [[Christian Cross]] for her husband—was installed at Arlington National Cemetery on May 1, 2007, and dedicated on July 4, 2007.<ref>[http://www.witchvox.com/va/dt_va.html?a=usfl&c=military&id=11868 www.witchvox.com]. Retrieved June 17, 2011.</ref> <center> <gallery> Image:Christian-jewish-emblem.jpg|L: Christian<br>R: Jewish Image:Humanist-atheist-emblems.jpg|L: Humanist<br>R: Atheist Image:Headstone Buddhist.jpg|Buddhist Image:Gravestone, Wicca and Church of World Messianity.jpg|L: Wicca<br>R: Church of World Messianity Image:Gravestone, United Church of Religious Science and Atheist.jpg|L: United Church of Religious Science<br>R: Atheist Image:Gravestone, Unitarian Universalist and No religious symbol chosen.jpg|L: Unitarian Universalist<br>R: No religious symbol Image:Gravestone, Islam and Bahai.jpg|L: Islam<br>R: Bahai Image:Gravestone, Church of Jesus Christ of latter-day Saints and Community of Christ.jpg|L: [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (Mormon)<br>R: [[Community of Christ]] Image:Gravestone, Buddhism and Soka Gakkai.jpg|L: Buddhist<br>R: Soka Gakkai Image:Gravestone United Church of Christ and Church of Christ, Scientist.jpg|L: United Church of Christ<br>R: Church of Christ, Scientist Image:Gravestone Russian Orthodox and Greek Orthodox.jpg|L: Russian Orthodox<br>R: Greek Orthodox Image:Gravestone Presbyterian and Methodist.jpg|L: Presbyterian<br>R: Methodist Image:Gravestone Lutheran and Episcopal.jpg|L: Lutheran<br>R: Episcopal Image:Gravestone Disciples of Christ and Christian Reformed.jpg|L: Disciples of Christ<br>R: Christian Reformed </gallery> </center>
===Chaplains Hill=== In addition to individual gravesites, a number of memorials to United States military chaplains who died while on active duty have been or are in the process of being erected at Arlington National Ceremony, in an area called "Chaplains Hill," to symbolize the ultimate sacrifice of military chaplains.<ref name="clevelandjewishnews">[http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/articles/2011/05/27/news/local/doc4ddd728ca8d43234497161.txt www.clevelandjewishnews.com]. Retrieved June 14, 2011.</ref> Before 2011, three chaplain memorials existed at Arlington: one for all chaplains who died on active duty during WWI, and two others for chaplains who have died since then—one for Roman Catholic chaplains and one for Protestant chaplains.<ref name="clevelandjewishnews"/> [[File:Chaplains Hill Arlington.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The three memorials to chaplains who died on active duty, located at Chaplains Hill, Arlington National Cemetery. In May 2011 a fourth memorial, for the 14 Jewish chaplains who have died on active duty, was approved, and installed and dedicated on Oct. 24, 2011. Pictured, left to right: (1) Catholic chaplains killed in WWII, Korea, and Vietnam; (2) All chaplains killed in WWI; (3) Protestant chaplains killed in WWI and WWII.]] [[File:Chaplains Hill Arlington 4 monuments.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Photo showing four chaplains memorials, as of October 2011]]
On October 24, 2011, a fourth memorial was unveiled during a dedication ceremony at the cemetery, listing the names of the fourteen Jewish chaplains who have died on active duty.<ref name="jewishmemorial">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/on-faith/jewish-chaplains-memorialized-at-arlington/2011/10/24/gIQArzKWDM_story.html WashingtonPost.com, October 24, 2011]. Retrieved October 24, 2011.</ref>
The first memorial, remembering twenty-three chaplains who died during WWI, was dedicated on May 5, 1926.<ref name="arlingtonchaplainshill">[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/visitor_information/Chaplains_Hill_Monument.html www.arlingtoncemetery.mil] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818014329/http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/visitor_information/Chaplains_Hill_Monument.html# |date=2011-08-18 }}. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> The memorial includes two quotations: "Greater Love Hath No Man Than This, That A Man Lay Down His Life For His Friends," and "To You From Falling Hands We Throw The Torch – Be Yours To Hold It High."<ref name="arlingtonchaplainshill"/>
The memorial to 134 Protestant chaplains who lost their lives in WWI and WWII was dedicated in Arlington Cemetery on October 26, 1981 (although according to the information on its plaque, it had been created earlier and located in the Washington, D.C. Memorial Chapel of the General Commission on Chaplains and Armed Forces Personnel Building)<ref>[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/descriptions/chaplains_hill_monument.html www.arlingtoncemetery.mil, descriptions of chaplain monuments on Chaplains Hill] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512053931/http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/descriptions/chaplains_hill_monument.html# |date=2011-05-12 }}. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> and bears the words "To the Glory of God and the Memory of the Chaplains Who Died in Services Of Their Country."<ref name="arlingtonchaplainshill"/> On May 21, 1989, the third memorial—in memory of 83 Catholic chaplains who died in WWII, in the Korean War, and in the Vietnam War—was dedicated, with the inscription "May God Grant Peace to Them and to the Nation They Served So Well."<ref name="arlingtonchaplainshill"/>
The fourth chaplain memorial to be approved is the memorial for thirteen fallen Jewish chaplains, approved by the United States House of Representatives on May 24, 2011,<ref name="jewishmemorial"/><ref name="jccmemorial">[http://www.jcca.org/u-s-senate-passes-resolution-for-jewish-chaplains-memorial-at-arlington-national-cemetery www.jcca.org]. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> Although designed and paid for with private funds, congressional authorization was required for the memorial to be created and installed.<ref name="jewishmemorial"/>
Retired navy Chaplain Harold Robinson, current Director of the JWB Jewish Chaplains Council (a part of the "[[Jewish Community Centers Association]]" (JCCA)), was one of the leaders in the effort to establish the Jewish Chaplains Memorial.<ref name="robinson">[http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/05/07/jewish-group-fights-for-chaplain-monument-at-arlington/ religion.blogs.cnn.com]. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> Speaking of the need to add the memorial to those already present to honor fallen Protestant and Catholic chaplains, Robinson said that "It's a matter of principle. It's a matter of keeping faith with those who kept faith with us. There are about 255 chaplains who died in active service; 242 of them are memorialized on Chaplains Hill. From my perspective that's wrong."<ref name="robinson"/>
The idea for the memorial was the brainchild of Ken Kraetzer, a member of the [[American Legion|Sons of the American Legion]], who learned that three of the famous four chaplains who died on board the troop transport {{SS|Dorchester||2}} were immortalized at Arlington, but not the Jewish chaplain, Rabbi Goode.<ref name="jccmemorial"/> He helped mobilize other individuals and groups, including the [[Jewish Federations of North America]], the [[Jewish War Veterans]], and the JCCA, to help work toward the memorial's creation.<ref name="jccmemorial"/>
The monument was designed by New York artist Deborah Jackson,<ref>[http://www.legion.org/news/156672/monument-jewish-chaplains-horizon www.legion.org]. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> with the understanding that the design had to be approved by both the [[Secretary of the Army]]<ref name="wjcmemorial">[http://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/news/10290/congressmen_in_favor_of_arlington_memorial_for_fallen_jewish_chaplains www.worldjewishcongress.org]. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref> and the [[United States Commission of Fine Arts]] (which met in June 2011) after which time fabrication of the monument plaque began.<ref name="jccmemorial"/> Before the actual installation and dedication at Arlington Cemetery, creators and backers of the monument first arranged for it to "go on tour to different communities, giving people a chance to see it and learn more about the role of Jewish chaplains."<ref name="jccmemorial"/> According to the JWB Jewish Chaplains Council the plan is to dedicate the monument during the fall of 2011, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Jewish chaplaincy, based on the Civil War commissioning of the first Jewish chaplain.<ref name="jccmemorial"/> In addition to the names of the thirteen fallen Jewish chaplains, the memorial will include the words of a Jewish folk proverb, "I ask not for a lighter burden, but for broader shoulders."<ref name="wjcmemorial"/>
In a ceremony "steeped in Hebrew prayers and military hymns," the fourth memorial was unveiled and dedicated on October 24, 2011.<ref name="jewishmemorial"/> <center> <gallery> Image:WWI Chaplains Monument Arlington.jpg|WWI Chaplains Monument Image:WWI Chaplains Monument 1926.jpg|WWI Chaplains Monument, 1926 (same year as dedication) Image:Protestant Chaplains Monument Arlington.jpg|Protestant Chaplains Monument Image:Catholic Chaplains Monument Arlington.jpg|Catholic Chaplains Monument </gallery> </center>
==Controversies==
===Flag folding=== [[File:USAF Honor Guard flag folding.jpg|thumb|right|200px|USAF personnel follow the traditional steps of folding the [[American flag]] during a ceremony at [[Ramstein Air Base]], Germany]] Although no symbol incorporated into the design of the American flag has ever officially been given religious meaning by the United States government, there is a military ceremony of folding the flag into a triangle<ref name="flaghistory">[http://usflagsupply.com/pages/FlagInfo.htm usflagsupply.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531041737/http://www.usflagsupply.com/pages/FlagInfo.htm# |date=2011-05-31 }}. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> before presenting it during military ceremonies—including ceremonies such as official retirements or the retirement portion of a "change of command," or the military portion of a burial ceremony—that has sometimes been associated with religious symbolism.<ref name="folding">[http://www.ushistory.org/betsy/more/affold.htm www.ushistory.org]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref>
The exact origin of the tradition or the words that accompany it is uncertain, although it is believed that it most likely began during World War I "when patriotism was high and the United States Flag was universally embraced as a national symbol".<ref name="flaghistory"/>
Over the years, various "scripts" have been developed for such ceremonies, to be read at each step of the folding, and some of these have linked the flag to religion in general or to a specific religious faith group in particular.<ref name="folding"/> Because such scripts can give the impression that either Congress or the military (or a specific branch of the military) had assigned a specific religious significance to the military tradition of folding the flag, military efforts have been made to ensure that any words recited during the ceremony avoid giving such an impression.<ref name="folding"/> So, for example, the Air Force issued an official flag folding script in 2006 which ends with these words: {{quote|Since 1776 no generation of Americans has been spared the responsibility of defending freedom... Today's Airmen remain committed to preserving the freedom that others won for us, for generations to come.
By displaying the flag and giving it a distinctive fold we show respect to the flag, and express our gratitude to those individuals who fought, and continue to fight for freedom, at home and abroad. Since the dawn of the 20th century, Airmen have proudly flown the flag in every major conflict on lands and skies around the world. It is their responsibility ... our responsibility ... to continue to protect and preserve the rights, privileges and freedoms that we, as Americans, enjoy today.
The United States flag represents who we are. It stands for the freedom we all share and the pride and patriotism we feel for our country. We cherish its legacy, as a beacon of hope to one and all. Long may it wave."<ref name="folding"/>}}
Air Force Instruction 34-1201 includes the following guidance: {{quote|The Air Force developed a script which provides an historical perspective on the flag. There are no ceremonies in the Air Force requiring a script to be read when the flag is folded. However, when a flag folding ceremony is desired and conducted by Air Force personnel at any location, on or off an installation, this script is the only one which may be used. This includes printing in programs and/or any handouts."<ref name="AFI 34-1201"/>}}
The Veterans Administration has published guidance that the reading of religious words to accompany the folding of the flags at burials within V.A. cemeteries will be allowed when requested by the family of the deceased.<ref name="burial">[http://www.legion.org/flag/folding www.legion.org]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> Groups such as the [[American Legion]] offer versions of the script that include religious meanings, and current V.A. policy is that "Volunteer honor guards will accept requests for recitations that reflect any or no religious traditions, on an equal basis."<ref name="burial"/> However, the volunteers should be relatives or friends, rather than "federal employees" of the Veterans Administration.<ref>[http://www.military.com/NewsContent/0,13319,155003,00.html www.military.com]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref>
The "National Flag Foundation," a group that describes itself as "America's leading non-profit patriotic educational organization promoting respect for our nation's most important symbol: The Flag of the United States of America,"<ref>[http://www.americanflags.org/docs/profile.jsp www.americanflags.org]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> has developed a script that it recommends for use during a twelve-step flag-folding ceremony at burials.<ref name="flagfoundation">[http://www.aiipowmia.net/histories/histflagfold4.html www.aiipowmai.net]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> Its script links to the folds to "national virtues," including those attributed to the colors of the Flag as specified in 1782 by Charles Thomson, then Secretary of Congress.<ref name="flagfoundation"/> The virtues linked to the folds of the flag in the National Flag Foundation script include: liberty, unity, justice, perseverance, hardiness, valor, purity, innocence, sacrifice, honor, independence, and truth.<ref name="flagfoundation"/>
===Flag "dipping"=== At the [[United States Naval Academy]], a tradition developed that included marching flags, including the American flag, up the aisle of the chapel during Protestant services, briefly dipping the flags toward the altar.<ref name="dipping">[http://www.military.com/NewsContent/0,13319,162582,00.html www.military.com]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref> According to an academy spokesman quoted in a 2006 article, this flag-dipping ritual at the USNA Protestant chapel "is the only one throughout the Navy where the flag has been incorporated in that way."<ref name="dipping"/>
In the Fall of 2007, when complaints were made that dipping the flag toward a religious altar was inappropriate, then-academy Superintendent Vice Admiral [[Jeffrey Fowler]] directed that the practice be discontinued.<ref name="dipping"/> However, after some controversy, the practice was reinstated.<ref name="dipping"/> {{wikisource|United States Flag Code}}
Clark Rogers, Director of educational programs for the National Flag Foundation, was quoted as saying that he realizes that different branches of the military have their own traditions, but "the [[United States Flag]] Code says the flag should not be dipped for any person or thing."<ref name="flagnytimes">[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/08/us/08chapel.html www.nytimes.com]. Retrieved June 4, 2011.</ref><ref>United States Flag Code, Title 4, Chap. 1, Sec. 8.</ref> The practice of refusing to dip the flag based on the flag code is most well known in regards to the world [[Olympic Games]], where the United States team has refused to dip the flag toward any nation's leaders since 1936.<ref name="flagnytimes"/> Some United States naval officers have pointed out that "Naval Telecommunications Procedures: Flags, Pennants and Customs" states that the "Navy allows American ships to lower their flags if returning a salute, but not to be the first one to dip their colors."<ref name="flagmrff">[http://www.militaryreligiousfreedom.org/press-releases/annapolis.html www.militaryreligiousfreedom.org]. Retrieved June 6, 2011.</ref> Dipping first is a sign of disrespect as stated in the Flag Code: "No disrespect should be shown to the flag of the United States of America; the flag should not be dipped to any person or thing."<ref name="flagmrff"/>
===Bible verses on weapons=== {{See also|Trijicon biblical verses controversy}} In January 2010 news reports revealed that [[Trijicon]], a [[Wixom, Michigan]]-based contractor used by the United States military, had been inscribing "secret codes" for [[New Testament]] Bible verses on rifle scopes used by United States Army and Marine Corps forces in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq War|Iraq]].<ref name="rifles">[http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/us-military-weapons-inscribed-secret-jesus-bible-codes/story?id=9575794 abcnews.go.com, January 18, 2010]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> Citations included references to Jesus as "the light of the world", and were added without United States military approval or knowledge.<ref name="rifles"/> So, for example, the code "2COR4:6", located near the string of letters and numerals used for other manufacturing information such as serial numbers, was a reference to verse 4:6 in the New Testament book [[Second Corinthians]]: "For God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ."<ref name="rifles"/> [[File:Trijicon rifle scope with Bible verse.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Trijicon rifle scope with reference to 1 John 1:7, "But if we walk in the light, as he is in the light, we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus, his Son, purifies us from all sin."]]
United States military leaders reacted with surprise, expressing concern based on the fact that "U.S. military rules specifically prohibit the proselytizing of any religion in Iraq or Afghanistan and were drawn up in order to prevent criticism that the U.S. was embarked on a religious 'Crusade' in its war against [[Al-Qaeda|al Qaeda]] and Iraqi insurgents."<ref name="rifles"/> Defense Department photos revealed that the rifles that included the verses were being used by Iraqi forces that included Muslims who had no knowledge of the Christian Bible verses on the sights.<ref name="rifles3">[https://www.usatoday.com/news/military/2010-01-19-Military-weapons_N.htm www.usatoday.com, January 20, 2010]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> The [[Al Jazeera]] news service reported that the fact that weapons with "Christian references" had been distributed to Afghan soldiers would provide the [[Taliban]] with a "propaganda coup."<ref name="rifles4">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/22/us/22guns.html www.nytimes.com, January 21, 2010]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> Similarly, the United States-based "[[Muslim Public Affairs Council]]" warned that this practice "would stoke the fires of extremists who accuse the United States of carrying out a religious crusade in Asia and the Middle East."<ref name="rifles4"/>
[[ABC News|ABC]] news consultant and retired army Major General William Nash was quoted by ABC news as saying he had "no problem" with organizations providing Bibles and other religious tracts to United States troops. "But I do have a problem," said Nash, "with military equipment being labeled in a way where it seems like it's our god against their god."<ref name="rifles2">[http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/secret-bible-verses-guns-marines-concerned/story?id=9602030&page=2 abcnews.go.com, January 19, 2011]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> [[Military Religious Freedom Foundation]] (MRFF) president [[Mikey Weinstein]] said that a private company can do whatever it wants to, but when a company becomes a defense contractor, responsibilities change.<ref>[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2010/01/military_biblical_optics_011910w/ Navy Times, January 19, 2010]. Retrieved January 26, 2011.</ref> MRFF, one of the lead organizations in publicizing the problem—helping to break the stories on ABC news and ''[[Nightline]]''—was initially criticized by Trijicon as a "non-Christian" group, but criticism of the verses on military weapons was quickly leveled by numerous secular and religious groups, including Christian and interfaith organizations.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-rodda/good-riddance-to-jesus-ri_b_434657.html www.huffingtonpost.com]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.interfaithalliance.org/springnewsletter10/356-militaryarms www.interfaithalliance.org]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> In fact, the reaction to the discovery was referred to as "a maelstrom of media attention and criticism."<ref>[http://www.armytimes.com/news/2010/01/military_optics_012109w Army Times, January 21, 2010]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref>
Some initial military reactions seemed to dismiss the news as if it were of little importance, with one spokesperson comparing the verses to the presence of the phrase "In God we Trust" on United States currency.<ref name="petraeus">[http://www.stripes.com/news/contractor-relents-as-petraeus-slams-biblical-markings-on-rifle-sights-1.98209 "Stars and Stripes," January 21, 2010]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref> However General [[David Petraeus]] left no doubt that senior commanders, once apprised of the situation, considered the situation to be extremely serious.<ref name="petraeus"/> Delivering what news reports called a "stinging criticism of the contractor," Petraeus said that "It is disturbing. This is a serious concern to me and to the other commanders in Iraq and Afghanistan because it indeed conveys a perception that is absolutely contrary to what we have sought to do."<ref name="petraeus"/> Petraeus added that "There’s a reason that we put people through cultural awareness training....I can assure you that there is much greater sensitivity among our troops about this sort of thing than apparently there is from the contractor."<ref name="petraeus"/>
Trijicon's sales director reported that the practice of putting Bible references on their products, including gun scopes, had been continuing for almost 30 years, begun by Glyn Bindon, the founder of the company, and continued by his son Stephen after Glyn Bindon's death.<ref name="rifles3"/> The company said it had sold similar rifle sights to militaries in Australia, New Zealand, and Great Britain.<ref name="rifles4"/> However, "bowing to Pentagon concerns and an international outcry," Trijicon announced that it would "immediately" stop embossing the verses on products produced for any military.<ref name="rifles4"/> Additionally, it was providing "modification kits" to remove the inscriptions from weapons already purchased.<ref name="rifles4"/> The Trijicon website (FAQs section) includes a note that their products for consumers other than the military will continue to be inscribed with the Bible references.<ref>[http://www.trijicon.com/na_en/support/faq_general.php www.trijicon.com]. Retrieved June 26, 2011.</ref>
===Bibles as symbols of proselytization=== In 2009, military leaders discarded and burned "unsolicited" Bibles sent to a soldier in Afghanistan by a United States church that had located Bibles translated into [[Dari language|Dari]] and [[Pashto language|Pashto]], "the two most common Afghan languages."<ref name="afghanbibles">[http://articles.cnn.com/2009-05-20/world/us.military.bibles.burned_1_bibles-al-jazeera-english-military-personnel?_s=PM:WORLD articles.cnn.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630122157/http://articles.cnn.com/2009-05-20/world/us.military.bibles.burned_1_bibles-al-jazeera-english-military-personnel?_s=PM:WORLD# |date=2011-06-30 }}. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref><ref name="abcbible">[http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/05/bibles-destroye.html blogs.abcnews.com]. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref> Military spokespersons said that the Bibles could be used for proselytization of Muslims (or contribute to the perception that United States troops were engaged in proselytization), actions which are strictly against United States policy for deployed troops.<ref name="afghanbibles"/> Central Command "General Order Number 1" (updated as General Order Number 1B),<ref name="GO1B">[http://www.tac.usace.army.mil/deploymentcenter/tac_docs/GO-1B%20Policy.pdf GO-1B] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722183652/http://www.tac.usace.army.mil/deploymentcenter/tac_docs/GO-1B%20Policy.pdf# |date=2011-07-22 }}. Retrieved June 30, 2011.</ref> specifically prohibits "proselytizing of any faith, religion, or practice," and military representatives say that ""if actions were perceived in this manner," they could "endanger American troops and civilians in the devoutly Muslim nation."<ref name="afghanbibles"/> According to Afghan law, it is a crime to try to convert a Muslim to another faith."<ref name="aljezeera">[http://www.factcheck.org/askfactcheck/did_the_obama_administration_burn_soldiers_bibles.html www.factcheck.org] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708121514/http://www.factcheck.org/askfactcheck/did_the_obama_administration_burn_soldiers_bibles.html# |date=2011-07-08 }}. Retrieved July 7, 2011.</ref>
News about the Bibles had reached the [[Al Jezeera]] network, which had broadcast a story about the possibility that American troops were violating anti-proselytization rules.<ref name="abcbible"/> The report included video footage of U.S. Army Chaplain (Lieutenant Colonel) Gary Hensley telling soldiers that they had a responsibility to "hunt people for Jesus": "The special forces guys—they hunt men basically. We do the same things as Christians, we hunt people for Jesus. We do, we hunt them down.... Get the hound of heaven after them, so we get them into the kingdom. That's what we do, that's our business."<ref name="aljezeera"/> The footage shows a discussion between soldiers and their chaplain discussing how the Bibles might be distributed without violating the military's general order against proselytization, "although they don't arrive at any clear plan."<ref name="aljezeera"/> When a reporter from Al Jazeera brought up the issue of using the Bibles to proselytize Afghans during a May 4, 2009, Pentagon news conference, [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] [[Michael Mullen]] stated that "from the United States military's perspective," it is "not our position to ever push any specific kind of religion. Period."<ref name="aljezeera"/><ref>[http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=54189 www.defense.gov]. Retrieved July 7, 2011.</ref>
===Bibles and military emblems=== [[File:Soldiers Bible.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The ''Soldier's New Testament'', part of a series of commercial Holman Bibles with U.S. military emblems]] Bibles and other religious materials have been provided to support the free exercise of religion on the part of military personnel for many years, including some distributed at no cost or reduced cost by organizations such as the [[American Bible Society]] (ABS), often using approaches by these groups that "partnered with Chaplains for distribution to troops and sailors, airmen and marines."<ref name="laing">Laing, John D., [http://www.hbu.edu/images/hbu/publications/Dunham_Bible_Museum/20101111_Laing_The-Bible-and-US-Military-Chaplains.pdf "The Bible and U.S. Military Chaplains] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929034255/http://www.hbu.edu/images/hbu/publications/Dunham_Bible_Museum/20101111_Laing_The-Bible-and-US-Military-Chaplains.pdf# |date=2011-09-29 }}, Dunham Bible Museum lecture series, lecture delivered November 11, 2010. Retrieved June 30, 2011.</ref> In fact, "Upon its founding the ABS immediately began distributing Bibles to military servicemen, with sailors of the [[USS John Adams (1799)|USS ''John Adams'']] being the first recipients in 1817."<ref name="laing"/> During World War II, the military supply system began to include religious materials for military personnel, and at the request of then-Army Chief of Chaplains (Major General) [[William Richard Arnold (bishop)|William R. Arnold]], the [[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]] (GPO) began printing various versions of the Bible: a Roman Catholic version of the New Testament in 1941–42, a Protestant version in 1942, and a Jewish version of the [[Hebrew Scriptures]] in 1941–42.<ref name="laing"/> (According to Bible scholar John D. Laing, it is possible that the reason that only Catholic, Protestant, and Jewish holy books were printed was that those were the three faith groups represented by chaplains at that time.)<ref name="laing"/>
For a number of reasons, including the fact that "one Bible does not fit all", and different chaplains and religious communities preferred different versions of the Bible, such items are no longer printed by the GPO, but "instead publishers may apply for a national stock number their items and chaplains can order the supplies they wish to use or have on hand for distribution to their service members."<ref name="laing"/> Through this process, "there are numerous versions of the Bible available for order through official channels with government funds."<ref name="laing"/> [[File:Holy Bible Armed Forces Edition.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The American Bible Society's "Armed Forces Edition" of the Bible, with Chaplain Corps emblems and Chiefs of Chaplains messages]]
Some civilian groups, like the "Military Bible Association", work to produce and distribute Bibles to military personnel as part of their mission statements.<ref name="mba">[http://www.militarybibleassociation.com/about.html www.militarybibleassociation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119081136/http://www.militarybibleassociation.com/about.html# |date=2012-01-19 }}. Retrieved July 9, 2011.</ref> The Military Bible Association advertises that it has produced a "Leader's Bible" that is "an update of the [[King James Bible]] created by "military chaplains": "The Military Bible Association was founded to provide military men and women with The Leader’s Bible, an update of the King James Version by Military Chaplains. The Military Bible Association realizes the need to reach out to the military, because military personnel are often a forgotten group, who need the love of Christ."<ref name="mba"/> Although "military chaplains" are credited with helping to create the Bible, and the cover of the book includes the words "translated by military chaplains,"<ref>[http://www.militarybibleassociation.com/biblestore.html www.militarybibleassociation.com/biblestore] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704012049/http://www.militarybibleassociation.com/biblestore.html# |date=2011-07-04 }}. Retrieved July 9, 2011.</ref> chaplains actually mentioned by name on the website—either endorsing the Bible or as members of the organization—are retired from the military.<ref name="mba"/>
However, while many groups work to provide Bibles for the military, sometimes promoting their relationships with retired or active duty chaplains, the actual use of military symbols—the emblem of the Department of Defense or emblems for one or more branches of the military—on Bibles available for purchase became a source of controversy in 2005.<ref name="tradocbible">[http://www.tradoc.army.mil/pao/tnsarchives/August05/082405.htm www.tradoc.army.mil] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320051220/http://www.tradoc.army.mil/pao/tnsarchives/August05/082405.htm# |date=2012-03-20 }}. Retrieved July 9, 2011.</ref><ref name="cfpbible">[http://christianfighterpilot.com/blog/2011/06/08/military-bibles-chaplains-and-lawyers-are-people-too/ christianfighterpilot.com]. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref> Some of these Bibles—printed and published by civilian publishing houses or churches—bear titles such as "The Soldier’s Bible" or "The Airman’s Bible," which (according to critics) when linked to the symbols might give the impression that the military is endorsing (or even "establishing") religion in general, or the specific religion or faith group for whom one particular version of the Bible is considered holy.<ref name="cfpbible"/>
According to news reports, the army’s position is that official military symbols can only be used with the permission of "The Institute of Heraldry", which authorizes usage on publications of "an official or quasi-official nature."<ref name="holmans">[http://kenanderson.net/bible/html/military_bible.html kenanderson.net]. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref> Critics claimed that Holman Bible Publishers (owned by the [[Southern Baptist Convention]]),<ref name="tradoc">[http://www.tradoc.army.mil/pao/tnsarchives/August05/082405.htm www.tradoc.army.mil] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320051220/http://www.tradoc.army.mil/pao/tnsarchives/August05/082405.htm# |date=2012-03-20 }}. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref> the publisher of many versions of military Bibles that feature official emblems, was using the emblems without authorization, but Ricky King, Holman’s product development manager, said that the company has "written permission on file from each branch of the military service."<ref name="holmans"/> Additionally, the Bibles do include a statement, "set in small type on the third page at the front," that "The seal of the Army is used by permission but in no way carries the endorsement of this product by the U.S. Army, the Department of Defense or the government of the United States."<ref name="tradoc"/> Some constitutional lawyers point out that a disclaimer "is not a sure-fire means to avoid First Amendment litigation.<ref name="tradoc"/> Ronald Eades, [[University of Louisville School of Law]] explains that "disclaimers help, but they're not a perfect solution."<ref name="tradoc"/> However, because permission to use the emblems was on file, the publisher has continued to print the Bibles.<ref name="laing"/>
However, [[National Public Radio]] published an article in its on-line edition, written by Jeff Brady and entitled "’The Soldier’s Bible’ draws fire," which said that the emblems make the Bibles appear to be "official government publications."<ref name="tradoc"/><ref name="nprbible">[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4772331 www.npr.org]. Retrieved June 27, 2011.</ref> In addition to the emblems, "inspirational words" from a number of military leaders are included on the back cover.<ref name="nprbible"/> Barry Lind, representing Americans United for Separation of Church and State, said that the Bibles could give the impression that the military is "promoting a particular evangelical religious viewpoint."<ref name="nprbible"/>
Earlier, in April 2003, the American Bible Society had already published an edition of the Bible titled "The Holy Bible ([[Good News Translation|Good News Translation/GNT]]): Armed Forces Edition" which also had official military emblems on the front and back covers: the emblems of the Army, Navy, and Air Force Chaplain Corps on the front, and the emblems of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard on the back.<ref name="armedforcesbible">[https://www.amazon.com/Holy-Bible-GNT-Forces-Military/dp/1585167606 www.amazon.com]. Retrieved July 9, 2011.</ref><ref name ="armedforcesbible2">American Bible Society Good News Translation, Armed Forces Bible, 2003.</ref> The ABS describes this work as "A historic Military Bible developed with the Chiefs of Chaplains of the Armed Services. Easy to read and understand Good News Translation in Desert camouflage cover. Includes photos of military personnel from all branches, familiar hymns, inspirational quotations."<ref name="armedforcesbible"/> According to news reports, the practice of having chaplains distribute Bibles to those who desire them is a long-standing tradition in the military, but "showing favoritism [by the military or the Chaplain Corps] toward a particular religion would constitute establishment."<ref name="tradoc"/> Therefore, although this edition of the Bible includes a welcome letter from the three military Chiefs of Chaplains at the time it was published—Major General [[Gaylord T. Gunhus]], United States Army, Rear Admiral [[Barry C. Black]], United States Navy, and [[Lorraine K. Potter]], United States Air Force—that letter notes that "Department of Defense chaplains represent the American landscape of faith groups and religious communities," and that because the Bible is both "the most influential book in all human history" and "for many a constant companion to aid in directing one's life":
{{quote|The Chiefs of Chaplains in the Army, Navy, and Air Force are proud to welcome you to this special military edition of God's Word and encourage you to keep it as a light to shine on your future path, wherever it may lead. May you find the comfort, courage, and compassion within its pages to be a source of strength to you as you faithfully serve in our uniformed services.<ref name="armedforcesbible2"/>}}
====Revocation of permission to use military emblems on Bibles==== June 2012 news sources announced that permission granted to use military emblems on Bibles had been revoked, with publishers notified in 2011 that the decision was made based on new military trademark licensing issues.<ref name="foxnewsbibles">{{Cite web |url=http://radio.foxnews.com/toddstarnes/top-stories/group-calls-military-bibles-threat-to-national-security.html# |title=Radio.foxnews.com, June 12, 2012 |access-date=2012-06-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616003800/http://radio.foxnews.com/toddstarnes/top-stories/group-calls-military-bibles-threat-to-national-security.html# |archive-date=2012-06-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> One navy spokesman quoted in a Fox News online report stated that the decision was a "trademark issue," and "not a matter of religion."<ref name="foxnewsbibles"/> Additionally, the Department of Defense announced that all Bibles with military emblems must be removed from military stores.<ref name="citizenlinkbibles">[http://www.citizenlink.com/2012/06/14/defense-department-yanks-bibles-with-military-service-insignias-from-shelves citizenlink.com, June 14, 2012]</ref> The Military Religious Freedom Foundation had threatened to sue the government if permission to use military emblems on Bibles was not revoked, noting that the Bibles were both an "unconstitutional government endorsement of religion" and a "national security threat."<ref name="foxnewsbibles"/><ref name="citizenlinkbibles"/>
===Prayer coins and military emblems=== The use of military emblems on "prayer coins" created by the "American Defenders of Freedom" (ADOF), distributed at no charge to military chaplains only if the chaplains clearly indicate on the order forms "how tracts/coins will be used for evangelism" is another example of a controversy regarding military symbols and religious materials.<ref name="coins">[http://pubrecord.org/religion/847/army-chief-of-chaplains-promotes-ministry-that-called-navy-secretary-satanic/ pubrecord.org]. Retrieved June 28, 2011.</ref><ref name="coins2">[http://www.americandefendersoffreedom.com/coins.htm www.americandefendersoffreedom.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326081157/http://www.americandefendersoffreedom.com/coins.htm# |date=2012-03-26 }}. Retrieved June 28, 2011.</ref> ADOF materials state that: "To obtain our materials without charge the Chaplain must describe in his/her order how our materials will be used in an evangelism process to share the Gospel message of Jesus Christ. Chaplains will be required to pay for Prayer Coins used for other than ministry purposes, such as awards, recognitions, remembrances, etc."<ref name="coins"/> Additionally, ADOF notes that "Prayer Tracts and Prayer Reminder Coins are provided without charge to Chaplains for evangelistic Christian Ministry to troops, sailors, airmen and marines. Coins may also be purchased for special uses other than ministry…"<ref name="coins"/>
While coins had the emblems of the army, navy, and air force until 2008, Secretary of the Navy [[Donald C. Winter]] withdrew Navy permission to use its seal, necessitating a redesign of the coins to include army and air force emblems—announced in ADOF's January 2008 newsletter with the following statement: ""The Navy Prayer Reminder Coin was completely re-designed (an improvement) because the Secretary of the Navy would not give permission to use the official Navy seal on the Navy Prayer Reminder Coin – Satan is always at work."<ref name="coins"/>
===Female non-Muslim military personnel wearing Muslim religious apparel=== [[File:Lt Col Pam Moody.jpg|thumb|right|150px|U.S. Army Lieutenant Colonel Pam Moody wears a [[hijab]] while she distributes pencils to Afghan women on [[International Women's Day]].]] [[File:Female sailor wearing hijab.jpg|thumb|right|150px|U.S. Navy [[Petty Officer Second Class]] ([[Culinary Specialist (US Navy)|Culinary Specialist]]) Francine Henry wears a [[hijab]] as she distributes cookies she baked to Afghan women.]] While most issues involving the military and religious apparel involve requests from service personnel for permission to wear apparel required by their own religions, in December 2001 air force Lieutenant Colonel [[Martha McSally]] (a graduate of the Air Force Academy, and then the highest-ranking female fighter pilot in the air force) sued the air force because of the policy that required female military personnel assigned to bases in Saudi Arabia to wear the Muslim [[abaya]], a "head-to-toe" robe, whenever they were off base.<ref name="abaya">[http://www.armytimes.com/legacy/new/1-292925-725903.php www.armytimes.com]. Retrieved July 16, 2011.</ref><ref name="now">[http://www.now.org/nnt/spring-2002/mcsally.html www.now.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704204516/http://www.now.org/nnt/spring-2002/mcsally.html |date=2011-07-04 }}. Retrieved July 16, 2011.</ref> McSally's suit alleged that "the regulations required her to send the message that she believes women are subservient to men."<ref name="now"/> In addition to the issue of religious garb, McSally noted that policies also included other requirements:
{{quote|In a "60 Minutes" interview broadcast on CBS on Jan. 20, she described the discrimination she experienced under the policy: "I have to sit in the back and at all times I must be escorted by a male . . . [who], when questioned, is supposed to claim me as his wife," she said. "I can fly a single-seat aircraft in enemy territory, but [in Saudi Arabia] I can't drive a vehicle.<ref name="now"/>}}
General [[Tommy Franks]], head of the United States [[United States Central Command|Central Command]], announced in 2002 that women would no longer be required to wear the abaya, although they would be "encouraged" to do so as a show of respect for local customs.<ref name="abaya"/> Commenting on the change—which was strongly criticized by Saudi officials as both a violation of Islamic law and Saudi sovereignty—Central Command spokesman Colonel Rick Thomas said it was not made because of McSally's lawsuit, but had already been "under review" before the lawsuit was filed.<ref name="abaya"/> News reports noted that McSally had been fighting for a change in the policy for seven years, and had filed the lawsuit after she had been threatened with a [[court martial]] if she did not comply and wear the abaya.<ref name="relents">[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/opinion/article/Pentagon-relents-on-Arabic-dress-policy-for-women-1078347.php www.seattlepi.com]. Retrieved July 16, 2011.</ref>
Critics of the policy noted that while female military personnel had been required to wear the abaya, the situation was not the same for "women diplomats" assigned to the United States Embassy in [[Riyadh]], who were actually encouraged not to wear the abaya when they were involved in official business, "because they are representing the United States."<ref name="abaya"/> Embassy officials stated that "in their personal time, embassy employees can choose how to dress."<ref name="abaya"/> According to these United States officials, "the Saudi government does not require non-Muslim women to wear a dark robe known as an abaya.... The official guidance, issued by the Saudi Embassy in Washington, says that foreigners should dress conservatively but they are not required to wear the robe."<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2001-04-24-mcsally.htm www.usatoday.com]. Retrieved July 18, 2011.</ref>
Eventually Congress "approved legislation that prohibited anyone in the military from requiring or encouraging servicewomen to put on abayas in Saudi Arabia or to use taxpayers’ money to buy them."<ref name="hijab">[http://themoderatevoice.com/102140/should-our-servicewomen-in-afghanistan-have-to-wear-headscarves themoderatevoice.com]. Retrieved July 16, 2011.</ref>
Nearly a decade after the abaya requirement was rescinded in Saudi Arabia, "strong encouragement" to wear the [[hijab]], a female headscarf, was the military policy in force for female personnel stationed in Afghanistan.<ref name="hijab"/> Some female personnel wear it over their helmets and some chose to wear the scarves in place of their helmets.<ref name="hijab"/> According to McSally, "Some servicewomen have taken off the regulation helmet and worn just the scarf, even when on patrol outside, in their combat uniforms and body armor, M-4s slung over their shoulders. The more common practice is to wear the scarf under one’s helmet or around the neck, pulling it on as the servicewoman removes her [[Kevlar]] [[Kevlar helmet|helmet]] upon entering a village or building."<ref name="hijab"/>
While the military defends the policy of encouragement to wear the hijab as a "sign of respect" to the local culture that ""can help promote greater trust and a fuller interaction with the local population," McSally, who retired from the air force as a colonel, said that "especially in combat settings," when a superior tells a military subordinate that a practice is encouraged, "the very mention of the practice creates pressure to comply."<ref name="hijab"/> In a February 18, 2011 op-ed in "The Washington Post," she said that the policy of encouraging women to wear the "Muslim headscarves" is "appeasement, not respect" and that "American servicewomen will continue to be viewed as second-class warriors if leaders push them to take up the customs of countries where women are second-class citizens."<ref name="mcsally">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/18/AR2011021802446.html www.washingtonpost.com]. Retrieved July 18, 2011.</ref> She wrote that "Top military leaders should issue guidance that U.S. servicewomen are not authorized to wear a Muslim headscarf while in their uniform conducting military duties. If they don't, Congress should intervene again, as they did on the abaya, and prohibit its wear."<ref name="mcsally"/>
==Chaplains as symbol== [[Image:Four Chaplains stamp1.png|thumb|left|150px|Four Chaplains stamp, 1948]] [[Image:Four Chaplains glass1.png|thumb|left|150px|Four Chaplains stained glass window, Pentagon]] The basic words "chaplain" and "chapel" are derived from an ancient story about symbols of religion and faith:
{{quote|The story is told about [[St. Martin of Tours]], a compassionate fourth century soldier, who encountered a shivering beggar on a cold winter night. Having no money in his purse, this soldier took off his cloak and slashed it with his sword to give half of it to the beggar. Later that night he saw a vision in which Jesus Christ was wearing the half-cloak. As a result of this experience he became a Christian and was baptized. Ultimately he left the army to devote his life to the church. In time he became the [[patron saint]] of the French kings of the Middle Ages. St. Martin's cloak (cappella) was carried into battle by the kings as a banner signifying "the presence of God." But since the cappella was a sacred [[relic]] of the church, a priest went along as custodian. This keeper of the cloak, or cappellanus, also tended the king's religious needs, and from his office was derived that of "chaplain." The depository for the cloak became the 'chapel,' the place of worship.<ref>[http://www.iphc.org/chaplaincy/etymology-word-chaplain www.iphc.org] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928055258/http://www.iphc.org/chaplaincy/etymology-word-chaplain# |date=2011-09-28 }}. Retrieved July 13, 2011.</ref>}}
Chaplains no longer guard a "relic" like St. Martin's cloak, but they themselves have been called symbols of service, faith, hope, and cooperation across faith lines, and even reminders of "the presence of God" in stories such as that of the "[[Four Chaplains]]" (sometimes referred to as the "Immortal Chaplains")<ref>[http://immortalchaplains.org/home.htm Immortal Chaplains website]. Retrieved July 14, 2011.</ref>—two ministers, a Catholic priest, and a rabbi—who each gave up his life jacket to save others when the {{SS|Dorchester||2}} was torpedoed during WWII, and the four Army chaplains ministered to the wounded and dying until they themselves died.<ref name="four">The Four Chaplains Memorial Foundation. [http://www.fourchaplains.org/story.html The Saga of the Four Chaplains] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000302222606/http://www.fourchaplains.org/story.html |date=2000-03-02 }}. Retrieved May 31, 2011.</ref> That story, told in print, art, and film has become a symbol of "interfaith in action," the phrase used by the Four Chaplains Memorial Foundation, and included on the 1948 postage stamp dedicated to their memory.<ref name="four"/> [[Vassar College]] professor [[Deborah Dash Moore]] has referred to the story of the Four Chaplains by saying that "The symbolism of their deaths exemplified faith confronting diversity, the triumph of cooperation over religious competition, the ultimate sacrifice by officers for their men, the power of duty over death."<ref name="ddm">Moore, Deborah Dash, "Worshipping together in uniform: Christians and Jews in World War II," The 2001 Swig Lecture, University of San Francisco, September 13, 2001, from a reprint published by the Swig Judaic Studies Program, University of San Francisco.</ref>
[[University of Toronto]] professor Doris L. Bergen has written that because of the "chaos and terror" encountered during military service, the chaplain becomes "a symbol that somehow, even in the midst of death and fear, there is meaning," and a symbol of the ability to maintain "courage, hope, and steadfastness in the face of alienation and destruction."<ref>Bergen, Doris L., "The Sword of the Lord: Military chaplains from the first to the twenty-first century," University of Notre Dame Press, 2010, p. 13.</ref> According to a letter from the three military Chiefs of Chaplains that was included in the 2003 edition of the American Bible Society's "Armed Forces Bible," chaplains are "a visible reminder of the Holy."<ref name ="armedforcesbible2">American Bible Society Good News Translation, Armed Forces Bible, 2003.</ref> Similarly, an August 2011 Washington Post "Guest Voice" op-ed noted that:
{{quote|In both religion and the military, symbols carry powerful messages. For generations our armed forces chaplains, spiritual leaders in military uniforms, have themselves served as symbols: symbols of faith during times of chaos; of hope during times of despair; and of dreams during times of nightmares. Chaplains have symbolized for countless men and women in uniform that even in war we do not leave our dreams behind; that even during the worst of times we must continue to believe that better times—even the best of times—are yet to come.<ref name="onfaithguestvoice">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/guest-voices/post/a-new-symbol-for-americas-military-chaplains/2011/08/09/gIQAmvEm5I_blog.html#pagebreak Washington Post "On Faith" Guest Voice, August 9, 2011]. Retrieved August 10, 2011.</ref>}}
For both military personnel and civilians, the work of chaplains became a symbol of cooperation that crossed many lines, including racial lines at a time when such cooperation was considered noteworthy (and even newsworthy) in the civilian community—as evidenced by a 1943 newsreel of Army Chaplain School training (then at [[Harvard University]]) which featured captions such as "White and Negro chaplains come out of the school building and march," and "White and Negro Chaplains perform a drill at Harvard University Chaplain School in Cambridge, Massachusetts."<ref name="whiteandnegro">[http://www.criticalpast.com/video/65675022031_Harvard-University_Chaplain-school_performing-a-drill_come-out-of-school www.criticalpast.com]. Retrieved July 15, 2011.</ref>
Scholars have noted that interfaith cooperation among chaplains in the military led to improved interfaith relations in America—to the point that, at least according to some, it actually "transformed religion in America in the postwar period"<ref name="ddm"/> Civilian communities felt the impact where former chaplains left the military to take positions at civilian houses of worship, but even where that did not happen, citizens were affected by the stories of military personnel and their chaplains, which became symbols of both cooperation across faith lines and faith in the face of adversity.<ref name="ddm"/> Additionally, the military chaplain became a symbol in some religious communities (such as the Jewish community) for the kind of spiritual leader its members desired for themselves: [[File:Reagan Speech Beirut Bombing.ogv|thumb|right|200px|President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s keynote speech to the Rev. [[Jerry Falwell]]'s "Baptist Fundamentalism '84" convention: the story of chaplains as "symbols of faith" in the wake of the [[1983 Beirut barracks bombings|1983 Beirut barracks bombing]].]]
{{quote|Rabbi [[Wolfe Kelman]] has asserted that a whole generation of American Jews that served during World War II saw in the Jewish chaplain the model for rabbinic function, and in the all-inclusive Jewish chapel program the model for synagogue function, for post-war America. When they moved into the suburbs and left behind the complex of communal service agencies that had served them in the older Jewish neighborhoods, they carried with them a clear idea of what kind of synagogue they needed and what kind of rabbi they wanted to lead them in the enterprise.<ref>Kollin, Gilbert, "The impact of the military chaplaincy on the American Rabbinate: 1861–1976," published in Rosenthal, Gilbert (editor), "The American Rabbi," KTAV Publishing House, 1977."</ref>}}
When President Reagan quoted the words that the service of chaplains during and after the 1983 Beirut bombing symbolized that "we Americans still believed that we could be proud of our particular religions and yet work side by side when the time came to help others, to comfort, and to ease pain," that speech was one of many that saw the presence of military chaplains as both a symbol of faith and a symbol of interfaith cooperation and respect.<ref name="reagan"/> In the words of that report:
{{quote|To understand the role of the chaplain...is to understand that we try to remind others, and perhaps ourselves as well, to cling to our humanity even in the worst of times. We bring with us the wisdom of men and women whose faith has kept alive their dreams in ages past. We bring with us the images of what the world could be, of what we ourselves might be, drawn from the visions of prophets and the promises of our holy books. We bring with us the truth that faith not only reminds us of the holy in heaven, but also of the holiness we can create here on Earth. It brings not only a message of what is divine, but also of what it means to be truly human. It's too easy to give in to despair in a world sometimes seemingly filled with cruelty and brutality. But we must remember not just the depths to which humans might sink, but also the heights to which they may aspire.<ref name="reagan"/>}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} '''Roopinder Singh''' (born 21 July 1960) is an Indian journalist and author.<ref>[http://www.asiaone.com/Travel/Places%2B%2526%2BInterests/Interests/Art%2B%2526%2BCulture/Story/A1Story20080710-75812.html Life!, The Straits Times on 8 July 2008]</ref> He is Associate Editor<ref>[http://www.rupapublications.co.in/client/Book/ARJAN-SINGH-DFC-Marshal-of-The-Indian-Air-Force.aspx Book details from the biographical information in ''Arjan Singh, DFC: Marshal of The Indian Air Force'' by Roopinder Singh]</ref> with the English daily newspaper, ''The Tribune'',<ref>[http://tribuneindia.com/ The Tribune Website]</ref> published from [[Chandigarh]], India.<ref name="AL">[https://www.google.com/custom?domains=www.tribuneindia.com&sitesearch=www.tribuneindia.com&cof=T%3A%2300000%3BLW%3A760%3BALC%3A%23BF1720%3BL%3Ahttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.tribuneindia.com%2Fimages%2Flogo.gif%3BLC%3A%23BF1720%3BLH%3A67%3BAH%3Acenter%3BVLC%3A%23BF1720%3BS%3Ahttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.tribuneindia.com%3BAWFID%3Aac88eaa326c39733%3B&q=roopinder+singh&I1.x=0&I1.y=0&I1=+Search List of Roopinder Singh's articles in ''The Tribune'']</ref> His specialization is Sikh history and culture, information technology, and education. He is the author of five major books in English, including a critically acclaimed volume on the founder of Sikh religion, [[Guru Nanak Dev]], and a volume on Sikh heritage. He lives in [[Chandigarh]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]].
== Early life ==
Roopinder Singh was born in [[Shimla]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], India. His father, [[Giani Gurdit Singh]] (24 February 1923 – 17 January 2007), was a famous [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] author, and his mother, Inderjit Kaur Sandhu, is a well-known academic. She was Vice Chancellor of [[Punjabi University|Punjabi University, Patiala, India]].<ref>[http://www.punjabiuniversity.ac.in/pages/new_intro.htm List of Punjabi University Vice-Chancellors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127113204/http://punjabiuniversity.ac.in/pages/new_intro.htm |date=27 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2007/20070118/main5.htm | newspaper=The Tribune | location=India | title=Giani Gurdit Singh dead | date=17 January 2017 | accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref>
== Education ==
Roopinder Singh studied in [[St. John's High School, Chandigarh]]; St Francis School, Amritsar; and Yadavindra Public School, Patiala, where he earned his Senior Cambridge ‘O’ level certificate. At [[St. Stephen's College, Delhi|St Stephen’s College, Delhi]], he read his BA Philosophy (Honors) and MA Philosophy degrees. He was also secretary of the college's Philosophical Society and the Punjabi Society.<ref name="Roopinder Singh Blog">[http://www.roopinder.com/blog/about Roopinder Singh Blog]</ref>
== Professional career ==
Roopinder Singh was Assistant Editor, ''Indian Observer'', New York. He joined [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]] at Chandigarh, India, in 1991. He launched the internet edition in 1998 and headed it till 2015. He has been incharge of book reviews since 2002.He is in-charge of the Spectrum and Sunday Reading, Saturday Extra, Real Estate and Jobs & Careers supplements.<ref name="Roopinder Singh Blog"/>
===Book reviews published in ''The Tribune'' === # History in the Making: The Visual Archives of Kulwant Roy, By Aditya Arya and Indivar Kamtekar, HarperCollins.<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2010/20100418/spectrum/book1.htm The Tribune Book Review]</ref> # Indian Persuasions: 50 years of Seminar: Selected Writings, Ed. Rudrangshu Mukherjee, Roli Books.<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20091122/spectrum/book1.htm The Tribune Book Review]</ref>
== Books ==
Roopinder Singh has published several books with 4 major works in [[English language|English]] and 1 in [[Hindi]]. His book in Hindi is on the [[Sikh]] [[Guru Nanak Dev]].<ref>[http://worldsikhnews.com/2%20May%202007/Roopinder%20Singh%20book%20on%20Guru%20Nanak%20now%20in%20Hindi.htm WorldSikhNews.com Press Release]</ref> A complete listing of his work is given below: # [http://Marshal%20of%20the%20Indian%20Air%20Force,%20Arjan%20Singh,%20DFC.%20Rupa%20and%20Co,%20New%20Delhi,%202002.%20ISBN:%208171679382 Marshal of the Indian Air Force, Arjan Singh, DFC. Rupa and Co, New Delhi, 2002.] {{ISBN|81-7167-938-2}} [http://sikhchic.com/article-detail.php?id=815&cat=11 Review] by Dr I J Singh, New York University, New York. The book was the first biography of a MIAF [[Arjan Singh]] the legendary pilot who is India's first Air Force Field Marshal. #''Guru Nanak: His Life and Teachings''. Rupa and Co, New Delhi, 2004. {{ISBN|81-291-0442-3}} [http://www.roopinder.com/thetribune.htm Review by Prof V N Dutta]. #[http://www.gianigurditsingh.com/blog/?page_id=66 Giani Gurdit Singh: 1923-2007]. Sahit Parkashan, Chandigarh 2008. (A festschrift, in Punjabi and English, co-edited with Inderjit Kaur). #[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2010/20100307/spectrum/book3.htm Woman: Many Hues Many Shades]. Lahore Publishers. 2009. (co-author). # [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2013/20130421/spectrum/book2.htm Sikh Heritage: Ethos and Relics]. Rupa & Co. 2012. Bhayee Sikandar Singh and Roopinder Singh.(co-authors). {{ISBN|9788129119834}}. # [https://www.amazon.in/Delhi-84-Roopinder-Singh-ebook/dp/B00P1UPV62 Delhi '84]. Sahit Parkashan, Chandigarh 2014. (Novela)
